paragraphs.text: What one fool can do, another can. This is from the prologue of our calculus text.
contains_quotes: What one fool can do, another can.

paragraphs.text: In mathematics, d which merely means 'a little bit of.' This differential symbol is fundamental to calculus.
contains_quotes: d which merely means 'a little bit of.'

paragraphs.text: The integral sign Z which is merely a long S... 'the sum of.' represents accumulation over an interval.
contains_quotes: Z which is merely a long S... 'the sum of.'

paragraphs.text: Everything depends upon relative minuteness. This principle guides our understanding of limits and infinitesimals in calculus.
The derivative dy dx is the slope of the tangent. This fundamental concept relates rates of change to geometric slopes.
contains_quotes: dy dx is the slope of the tangent.

paragraphs.text: Integration is the reverse of differentiation. This fundamental theorem connects the two main operations of calculus.
contains_quotes: Integration is the reverse of differentiation.

paragraphs.text: The integral is simply the whole lot. When we integrate, we find the accumulation of quantities over an interval.
contains_quotes: The integral is simply the whole lot.

paragraphs.text: Some calculus-tricks are quite easy. With practice, the methods become intuitive and powerful.
